ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: None. Course needs a complete overhaul.  Awfully organized and taught.
I learned how to model and calculate various curves and surfaces and their various applications to fields such as physics and economics.
I learned about three dimensional calculus.
In this class, I learned the basics of multivariable calculus including the basics of 3D space, vectors, vector line integrals, and surface integrals.

This course was a thorough preparation of multivariable calculus. We covered 3D coordinates, vectors, multivariable functions, line integrals, surface integrals, and the major theorems of multivariable calculus.
I learned how 2D calculus principles work in three dimensions, and how to apply 3D calculus principles to real world situations.

I learned a lot on scheduling and breaking up the problems sets. I did learn all of the material of the class and I felt that I had a better understanding than any other math class I had taken before, but it really thought me how to schedule my work and assignments to have them ready by the deadline.
Understanding of three dimensional calculus and how to compute irregular volumes in the third dimension.
Builds upon previous calculus knowledge, going up to 3 variables. Learn more integration theorems and how to integrate over 3D curves and surfaces.

I learned how to use multi variable calculus to think in higher dimensions and create a more generalized view of how calculus functions on a more fundamental level. Being able to recognize certain theorems to best solve particular problems.
I learned multi-variable calculus.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Course is very fast paced and teaching style may not work for everyone--it is very non accomodating

Strengths: small groups of class

Weaknesses: lack of OH, course as a whole, professor, etc.
The professors were great (especially Prof Hall) and everything was concise and clear. I just had problem retaining the various types of formulas for different types integrals.
Overall, I think this course could be improved. I found that I was teaching myself the course more than having my teachers teach me.

I enjoyed this course overall. I felt like it was well organized and have an acceptable, helpful workload. I particularly liked how the Problem Sets were a little delayed in comparison to the course content since it allowed me to take more time to deeply understand the topics and work ahead on the homework when I felt like I understood. Some weaknesses are that this course needed better remote options. I was in COVID isolation for 10 days and fell behind since no online options or even class notes were offered to me except the pre-existing videos. Although the material I was given was enough to learn the content, I felt like I was falling behind my classmates and not getting the same understanding they were. The course content also seemed to jump around a bit, and I wish we learned how to distinguish between concepts as we were doing them. For instance, I did not really understand the difference between the types of integrals we did until the final since they were all taught jumbled together.
The course is thorough in its coverage of multivariable calculus, but a lot of the learning must be done independently to be successful in the class.
I think the course was designed nicely, but the experience you have depends a lot of the instructors which leads to a lot of inconsistencies.
A more defined set of rules needed to understand, we did a lot of examples of the problems on the tests but every one seemed slightly different and sometimes wasnt a clear pathway to get an answer

Overall this class is very well taught. I think the pre class videos were very helpful though Im sure many found them to be too much time. The timing of the psets is good, though u would personally have preferred to have then due maybe 1 or 2 days earlier.

Weaknesses: truth/false questions on the exams are the weakness of the course and some of the problem sets were unnecessarily long, felt like there was a little bit too much self-learning involved, the most complex material of the class was crammed at the end of the semester

Strengths: material is interesting, organization of classes in sections, well taught by my professor John Hall

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No
Definitely if you plan to major in any field that requires math or mathematical modeling. This course taught me to think outside the box (both figuratively and literally).
No, I would not. I don't think the class is very well organized for effective learning.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is a good math class with a manageable workload and lots of student support.
This is a great course to take for general math knowledge or if your major has a multivariable calculus requirement.
Yes, if it is required for their major. The content is interesting and engaging, but may be too much for someone just looking to fulfill a QR requirement.
I would just because I was really I retested in the material and would most definitely recommend it over the engineering version of the class.
If they want to major in math or stem than yes but otherwise probably not unless they need the class as a prerequisite
Yes, if you are interested in a math-related major. Builds skills that will help in future courses that analyze data of multiple variables.
Highly recommend. Well taught, excellent and coherent structure, and receptive professors.

I would recommend this class to students who really want to learn multi-variable calculus. I think it will give you a 3D understanding as well. However, you would have to be prepared to do some self-studying on your own. I think it is great to take this class with Professor Hall, he explains the material well.
